name: Chop
dis: One of the biggest occasions in Bangladesh is the Muslim celebration of Ramadan. One of the most popular foods for iftar is Chop.

name: Falooda
dis: Falooda is a well known cold dessert made by mixing rose syrup and sweet basil seeds with milk, noodles, ice cream, and vermicelli.

name: Bengali Mutton Curry
dis: Sunday afternoons are synonymous with Mutton Curry and Rice in any quintessential middle-class Bengali household

name: Fish Curry
dis: Fish curry, or machha jhola, is a traditional spicy fish curry in Bengali and Odia cuisines in the eastern part of the Indian subcontinent.

name: Aloo Posto
dis: This is a traditional Bengali dish prepared using potatoes lightly spiced with poppy seed paste.

name: Shorshe Ilish
dis: A popular dish from the wetlands of Bengal, stretching across borders between India and Bangladesh

name: Ilish Paturi
dis: Ilish Macher Paturi combines three of Bengal’s greatest loves – the Hilsa fish, the banana plant, and mustard.

name: Aam Tel Ilish
dis: Aam Tel Ilish which is mango pickle-flavored, steamed boneless Hilsa wrapped in a pumpkin leaf and served in a clay pot with steamed rice

name: Macher Chop
dis: Calcutta being the administrative center of the British Raj in India has adopted various techniques and recipes and added their own culinary twist.

name: Bengali Mishti Pulao
dis: Bengal is famous for its variety of sweets made with milk, milk fudge, and cheese. Just as famous as the sweet Misthi Pulao, Basmati is the choice of rice.
